facts.text: Suit property is a Mahal of 84 Bighas 18 Cottas situated within lot Ahiyapur village, part of permanently settled estate of Burdwan Zamindari.
Village granted by Maharaja of Burdwan in Patni settlement to predecessors-in-title of defendants 1 to 7 prior to Bengal Regulation VIII of 1819.
Suit lands were Chaukidari Chakaran lands set apart at or prior to permanent settlement for village watchmen.
Village Chaukidari Act, 1870 (Ben. VI of 1870) passed; s.48 provided transfer of Chaukidari Chakaran lands to zamindar; ss.50-51 governed transfer subject to prior contracts.
Suit properties transferred to Maharaja of Burdwan under the Act.

On June 3, 1899, Maharaja granted suit lands to predecessors-in-title of defendants 1 to 7 (Exhibit B) at yearly rental Rs. 126-8 as., with payment terms to Panchayat and Zamindar; default clause for sale under Regulation VIII of 1819.
Maharaja applied under s.8 of Regulation for sale due to arrears; auction on May 15, 1937, purchased by Maharaja himself.
On February 13, 1941, Maharaja granted lands on Patni to appellant (plaintiff).
Appellant filed Title Suit No. 7 of 1946/27 of 1947 in Court of Additional Sub-Judge, 1st Court, Burdwan for ejectment alleging trespass by defendants.
Defendants contested suit claiming no arrears under Exhibit B, sale void.
Sub-Judge (judgment Sept 25, 1948) held arrears due, defendants failed to sue under s.14 Regulation within time, decreed for plaintiff.
District Judge, Burdwan (Title Appeal No. 247/16 of 1948, judgment Aug 29, 1950) dismissed defendants' appeal; held Exhibit B created new Patni, sale valid, s.14 bar applied.

Calcutta High Court (Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 971 of 1950, judgment March 21, 1952, Das Gupta and Lahiri JJ.) allowed second appeal; held Exhibit B made lands part of lot Ahiyapur Patni, sale void as partial, s.14 inapplicable; dismissed suit.
Supreme Court appeal on certificate under Art. 133(1)(a).

legal_issues.text: Whether the point that Exhibit B incorporated suit lands into lot Ahiyapur Patni making sale invalid as partial Patni could be raised for first time in appeal.
True character of grant under Exhibit B: new distinct Patni or incorporation into existing lot Ahiyapur Patni.
If sale invalid as partial Patni, whether s.14 of Regulation VIII of 1819 bars collateral challenge after limitation period.

petitioner_arguments.text: Defendants did not raise plea in written statement or trial that Exhibit B made lands part of lot Ahiyapur Patni; point should not be allowed in appeal.
Exhibit B properly construed creates new Patni distinct from lot Ahiyapur; sale valid.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Construction of document; precedents like Mohadeb Mundul v. Mr. H. Cowell; Monomothonath Dev v. Mr. G. Glascott

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if sale invalid as partial tenure, defendants' only remedy was suit under s.14 Regulation within time; cannot attack collaterally in ejectment suit.

respondent_arguments.text: No arrears due under Exhibit B; sale void.
Exhibit B made suit lands part and parcel of lot Ahiyapur Patni; sale of portion illegal and void.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Clauses in Exhibit B linking to lot Ahiyapur; Kanchan Barani Debi v. Umesh Chandra

respondent_arguments.text: Void sale as partial Patni not saved by s.14 Regulation.

court_reasoning.text: First contention rejected: nature of Exhibit B is pure question of law on document construction; no evidence needed; no objection in District Court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Well-settled no evidence admissible on construction; cites Balkishen Das v. Legge; Maung Kyin v. Ma Shwe La.

court_reasoning.text: Rights under s.51 Village Chaukidari Act: Patnidar entitled to lands subject to assessment and fair rent; grant like Exhibit B recognizes right and fixes rent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Grant can be continuation/accretion to original Patni or new distinct Patni by agreement.

court_reasoning.text: Exhibit B construed as whole creates distinct new Patni: recital of new settlement, sale clause under Regulation implies separateness, transfer/succession clauses treat as independent; later clauses reconciled as indemnity and cesser on major Patni sale.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule: prefer construction giving effect to all clauses (ut res magis valeat quam pereat); earlier sale clause prevails if conflict (Forbes v. Git).

court_reasoning.text: Kanchan Barani Debi v. Umesh Chandra distinguished: did not consider sale clause effect.
Held Exhibit B created new Patni; sale not bad as portion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Issue on validity resolved by i2; s.14 not reached.

holdings.text: Point on construction of Exhibit B allowable in appeal as question of law.
Grant under Exhibit B (June 3, 1899) created a new and distinct Patni separate from lot Ahiyapur Patni.
Sale of lands comprised in Exhibit B on May 15, 1937 not invalid as sale of portion of Patni.

precedents_cited.relevance: No evidence admissible on construction of contract/grant.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maung Kyin v. Ma Shwe La
precedents_cited.relevance: No evidence on document construction relating to existing facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ranjit Singh v. Maharaj Bahadur Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: s.51 Village Chaukidari Act saves real rights of Patnidar.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhupendra Narayan Singh v. Narapat Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Zamindar entitled to fair rent on Chaukidari lands in Patni.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rajendra Nath Mukherjee v. Hiralal Mukherjee
precedents_cited.relevance: Patnidar liability for rent on Chaukidari lands.
Patnidar liability for rent on Chaukidari lands.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohadeb Mundul v. Mr. H. Cowell
precedents_cited.relevance: Separate sanads for portions create distinct Patnis salable independently.

precedents_cited.case_name: Monomothonath Dev v. Mr. G. Glascott
precedents_cited.relevance: Separate sanads for portions create distinct Patnis salable independently.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kanchan Barani Debi v. Umesh Chandra
precedents_cited.relevance: Held similar grant part of original Patni but ignored sale clause.
Earlier clause prevails over later repugnant clause.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Patni Taluks Regulation, 1819
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs sale for arrears; s.14 limits time to challenge sale; sale of distinct Patni valid.

statutes_cited.name: Village Chaukidari Act, 1870 (Ben. VI of 1870)
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer of Chaukidari lands to zamindar subject to prior contracts; Patnidar rights saved.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, reversed Calcutta High Court judgment, held Exhibit B created new distinct Patni, sale valid; implied restoration of decree for plaintiff in ejectment suit.
outcome.relief_granted: Suit for ejectment decreed in favor of appellant/plaintiff.

key_quotes.text: "Exhibit B properly construed must be held to create a new Patni distinct from lot Ahiyapur, and its sale is therefore valid."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel

key_quotes.text: "Construing Exhibit B, as a whole, we are of opinion that the intention of the parties as expressed therein was that the Chaukidari Chakaran lands should be held as a distinct Patni."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "if there be admissible two constructions of a document, one of which will give effect to all the clauses therein while the other will render one or more of them nugatory, it is the former that should be adopted on the principle expressed in the maxim ut res magis valeat quam pereat."
key_quotes.speaker: court
